earthquakeSafety.title: Drop, Cover and Hold
earthquakeSafety.subtitle: Click here to view precautions for actions at home
details: DROP down on your hands and knees. This protects you from falling over but lets you move if you need to.

COVER your head and your neck (or your entire body if possible) under a sturdy table or desk (if it is within a few steps of you). If there is no shelter nearby, cover your head and neck with your arms and hands.
HOLD on to your shelter (or your position to protect your head and neck) until the shaking stops. If the shaking shifts your shelter around, move with it.
Turn off gas appliances

earthquakeSafety.title: Safe Places in Open Areas
earthquakeSafety.subtitle: Click here to view precautions for safe places in open areas
details: If you are outside, find a clear area away from buildings, trees, streetlights, power lines, unstable slopes and cliffs: these may fall and cause injuries during an earthquake.
Avoid overpasses and bridges
Drop and Cover: Drop down on your hands and knees and cover your head and neck with your arms. Stay where you are until the shaking stops.

earthquakeSafety.title: Safety Measures in Vehicles
earthquakeSafety.subtitle: Click here to view precautions for safety measures in vehicles
details: Pull over: to a clear location, away from trees, power lines, poles, street signs, overpasses, cliffs, and other overhead items, that may fall during earthquakes.
Stay inside the vehicle until shaking stops
There may be more emergency vehicles on the road than normal. Make sure you allow them past as soon as it is safe to do so.

earthquakeSafety.title: First Aid Information
earthquakeSafety.subtitle: Click here to view first aid information
details: Check for injuries and provide first aid
If someone is unconscious, call emergency services
Treat bleeding with direct pressure
Provide comfort and reassurance

earthquakeSafety.title: Essential Supplies to Keep
earthquakeSafety.subtitle: Click here to view the list of essential supplies to keep
details: Water (1 gallon per person per day)
Non-perishable food items
First aid kit
Medications
Flashlight with extra batteries
Blankets
Emergency cash
Personal hygiene items
Multi-tool or Swiss Army knife
Duct tape
Important documents (ID, insurance, etc.) in a waterproof container
Whistle for signaling
Portable phone charger
Extra clothing and sturdy shoes
N95 masks for dust and debris
Moist towelettes and garbage bags for sanitation
Emergency contact list with addresses and phone numbers

earthquakeSafety.title: As soon as the shaking stops
earthquakeSafety.subtitle: Click here to view the emergency plan
details: Check yourself for injuries and get first aid if necessary. Help others if you can.
If you are in a tsunami evacuation zone you need to move to higher ground immediately, or as far inland as you can, out of tsunami evacuation zones.
Look quickly for damage around you, particularly in buildings where furniture and fittings may have become hazardous.
Look for small fires and, if safe to do so, extinguish them.
If you can, put on protective, weather appropriate clothing that covers your arms and legs and sturdy footwear in case you have to move through debris.
If you are in a store, unfamiliar commercial building, or on public transport, follow the instructions of those in charge.

Do not run outside unless the building is showing obvious signs of distress, or you are in a tsunami evacuation zone. It is frightening to stay in a building, but it is much safer than immediately going outside, where masonry and glass could fall on you.
Your usual fire evacuation assembly area might not be a safe location after an earthquake if it is exposed to falling glass and masonry.

earthquakeSafety.title: Precautions for Pets
earthquakeSafety.subtitle: Click here to view precautions for pets
details: Prepare an emergency kit for each pet with food, water, and medications
Identify pet-friendly shelters in advance
Ensure pets have proper identification
Include pet toys and comfort items in their emergency kit
Microchip pets for easy identification

earthquakeSafety.title: Electrical and Gas Shutdown Procedures
earthquakeSafety.subtitle: Click here to view electrical and gas shutdown procedures
details: Turn off gas valves if safe to do so
Switch off electrical circuit breakers
Avoid using matches or lighters until gas is confirmed off
Inspect for gas leaks using a soap and water solution
Know the location of the main water and gas shutoff valves in your home
